column1: Oakenshield was the title and sobriquet of King Thorin of Durins Folk.
Thorin acquired the title long before he became King. In  when he was just fifty-three (a young age for a Dwarf) he marched with a mighty Dwarf-army to the valley they called Azanulbizar
column2: Nanduhirion beneath the Great Gates. There they fought the Battle of Azanulbizar
column3: the last and greatest in the War of the Dwarves and Orcs. In that battle
column5: so he cut a bough from an oak-tree with his axe
column6: and used that instead to fend off his enemies blows
column7: or to club them. It was that oaken branch that gave Thorin his surname
column8: but it did not completely save him from injury - it is recorded that he was wounded in the battle.  In memory of the battle
column9: Thorin bore a plain shield of oak wood with no device
column10: and swore to do so until he was hailed king.

column2: it appears in the Norse poem Völuspá in the form Eikinskjaldi
column3: but there it is the personal name of a Dwarf
column4: not a surname as in Tolkiens work.

column1: Tolkien fandom have speculated that Tolkien may possibly have been inspired by a Wikipedia:Kvæði
column3: in which Wikipedia:Sigurd uses an oak tree branch as a weapon:

column2: and lammed those lads so lustily
